item.title: Top National Book Awards Go to Writing About the Middle East
item.description: Rabih Alameddine’s “The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother)” won in fiction, while Omar El Akkad’s reckoning with Gaza took the nonfiction prize.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.category: One Day, Everyone Will Have Always Been Against This (Book)
The True True Story of Raja the Gullible (and His Mother) (Book)
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Omar El Akkad accepting the 2025 National Book Award for nonfiction on Wednesday night.

item.title: Sizzling New Romance Books
item.description: Our columnist on three books worth your time.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Waite

item.title: Book Review: ‘Mexico,’ by Paul Gillingham
item.description: In a new book, Paul Gillingham tells the story of a nation that has thrived because of its diversity, not in spite of it.
item.dc:creator: Álvaro Enrigue
item.media:description: A 17th-century depiction of the Spanish conquest of Tenochtitlán, the capital of the Aztec empire.

item.title: Dazzling New Historical Fiction Books
item.description: Our columnist on four books that are worth your time.
item.dc:creator: Alida Becker
item.category: The Girl in the Green Dress (Book)

item.title: David Bellos, 80, Dies; Wrestled French Wordplay Into English
item.description: He translated nearly 30 books, including novels by Georges Perec, a master of linguistic games, and Ismail Kadare.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Who Owns This Sentence? A History of Copyrights and Wrongs (Book)

item.title: Books Our Editors Love This Week
item.description: Reading recommendations from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: The Girl in the Green Dress (Book)

item.title: Stephen Anderson, Linguist Who Refuted Doctor Dolittle, Dies at 82
item.description: In “Doctor Dolittle’s Delusion,” he argued that language is a biological system unique to humans, despite the widespread belief that it extended to other animals.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Richard Lamparski, Author of ‘Whatever Became Of …?’ Books, Dies at 93
item.description: He turned an obsession with forgotten stars into a popular series, long before “Where Are They Now?” features became ubiquitous.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Superman Comic Sets Auction Record, Selling for $9.12 Million
item.description: A family’s forgotten copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was sold by Heritage Auctions.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.media:description: A high-grade copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was discovered by a family last year and sold for $9.12 million at auction.

item.title: How to Make That Restaurant Dessert at Home? Ask David Lebovitz.
item.description: David Lebovitz has built a loyal following online with recipes that offer shortcuts but make no compromises.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin
item.media:credit: Matthew Avignone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Lebovitz, one of the original food bloggers, has kept his devoted following since moving to Paris — and to Substack.

item.title: George Packer on His Favorite Books and His New Novel, ‘The Emergency’
item.description: “Journalism is essential, but it can’t get at certain levels of experience — so I wrote a fable,” he says of “The Emergency,” his first novel in more than 25 years.
item.category: Last Best Hope: America in Crisis and Renewal (Book)

item.title: These Books Were Judged by Their A.I. Covers, and Disqualified
item.description: A New Zealand book competition dropped two of a publisher’s books because they had A.I.-generated covers. The publisher and the designer pushed back.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Butterfly Thief,’ by Walter Marsh
item.description: In “The Butterfly Thief,” Walter Marsh tells the story of a notorious crime and its eccentric perpetrator.
item.dc:creator: Sam Kean
item.category: The Butterfly Thief: Adventure, Empire, and Australia's Greatest Museum Heist (Book)

item.title: ‘This World of Tomorrow’ Review: Tom Hanks Is Back in Town
item.description: The movie star plays a man from the future at the 1939 New York World’s Fair in an adaptation of some of his stories. Kelli O’Hara shines as his love interest.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: Tom Hanks, Kayli Carter and Kelli O’Hara in “This World of Tomorrow” at the Shed in Manhattan.

item.title: Solvej Balle Took 30 Years to Write ‘On the Calculation of Volume.’ It’s a Sensation.
item.description: The Danish author Solvej Balle’s experimental opus reframes the tedium of contemporary life as a source of unexpected wonders.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Zhou
item.media:credit: Giulia Mangione for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solvej Balle in her garden in Denmark.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Breath of the Gods,’ by Simon Winchester
item.description: In “The Breath of the Gods,” the prolific polymath takes on a force that’s powered much of human history.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Hammer
item.media:description: The wind’s power, writes Simon Winchester, can be harnessed for good or cause misery — like the Dust Bowl of the 1930s, which devastated a landscape and displaced thousands.

item.title: The Secret to Getting Through Big, Dense, Difficult Books
item.description: Learning is painful, pleasant and, above all, communal.
item.dc:creator: Sebastian Castillo

item.title: New to Cyberpunk Books? Here’s Where to Start.
item.description: The science fiction writer Chloe Gong recommends new and classic books that push the boundaries of the genre, with plenty of techno thrills.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gong
item.media:credit: Author photo by One Grid Studio

item.title: Book Review: ‘A Certain Lucas,’ by Julio Cortázar
item.description: A newly reissued book by the Argentine writer Julio Cortázar highlights his most consistent qualities.
item.dc:creator: Martin Riker

item.title: How Joan Didion Did Thanksgiving
item.description: The author’s newly unveiled papers reveal the meticulous planning and devotion to cooking that went into her big holiday meals.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Farrell
item.media:credit: Henry Clarke/Condé Nast via Getty Images

item.title: Sex Had Become a Chore. Then They Started Reading Romantasy.
item.description: The wildly popular fiction genre allows readers to talk openly about yearning, sex and desire. And it’s spilling over into their bedrooms.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: A Court of Thorns and Roses (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘Baby Driver,’ by Jan Kerouac
item.description: Jan Kerouac’s 1981 novel “Baby Driver” chronicles a fearless and windblown life entirely distinct from her famous parent’s.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.media:credit: Fred W. McDarrah/The New York Historical, via Getty Images

item.title: Book Review: ‘Lovers and Haters,’ by Gilbert Hernandez
item.description: With “Lovers and Haters,” Gilbert Hernandez expands on the surreal storytelling and bosomy B-movie film stars of his beloved long-running series.
item.dc:creator: Sam Thielman
item.category: Lovers and Haters: A Love and Rockets Book (Book)

item.title: Broadway’s Radical ‘Oedipus,’ With Mark Strong and Lesley Manville
item.description: Icke dusts off the classics the way a restorer brightens an old master painting. His latest project stars Mark Strong and Lesley Manville.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The actors Mark Strong, left, and Lesley Manville with the writer and director Robert Icke.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Pelican Child,’ by Joy Williams
item.description: At its best, Joy Williams’s “The Pelican Child” is delightfully unhinged; at its worst, willfully weird and repetitive.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.media:credit: The New York Times, photos via Everett Collection/Bridgeman Images, Associated Press

item.title: Creepy New Psychological Thrillers
item.description: Our columnist on three novels thrumming with menace.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall

item.title: Poetry Review: ‘The Poems of Seamus Heaney’ Is Complete, and Great
item.description: Even the previously uncollected work in “The Poems of Seamus Heaney” shows a master craftsman in full control of his powers.
item.dc:creator: Robert Pinsky

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Fire,’ by Cecilia Sala
item.description: In “The Fire,” the reporter Cecilia Sala travels to Iran, Ukraine and Afghanistan and follows her generation into the fray.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Margalit
item.category: The Fire: Voices of a Generation in Iran, Ukraine, and Afghanistan (Book)
item.media:description: An open-air charity event for the production of military equipment at a nightclub in Kyiv, in 2023.

item.title: “Convent Wisdom” Looks to Nuns from Yesterday to Help Make It Through Today
item.description: The unlikely collaboration of two academics, “Convent Wisdom” provides unholy guidance by intertwining religious history with popular culture.
item.dc:creator: María Sánchez Díez

item.title: James Baldwin’s Biographer on the Meaning of Love
item.description: In “Baldwin: A Love Story,” Nicholas Boggs focuses on the writer’s romantic relationships. In this episode he explains their importance to Baldwin’s life and work.
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Noah Loof

item.title: Book Review: ‘Crick,’ by Matthew Cobb
item.description: In “Crick: A Mind in Motion,” the British biologist Matthew Cobb provides a biography both vivid and authoritative.
item.dc:creator: Janice P. Nimura
item.media:description: Francis Crick made scientific history as the co-discoverer of DNA’s structure, conferring on him what the biologist Matthew Cobb terms “the Crick halo.”

item.title: In Death, Poet Andrea Gibson Gets a Film That Celebrates Life
item.description: “Come See Me in the Good Light” follows the writer and their wife as they experienced the pain of cancer and also the joy of living.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.category: Come See Me in the Good Light (Movie)

item.title: Book Review: “The Incredibly Human Henson Blayze,” by Derrick Barnes
item.description: In Derrick Barnes’s fantastical tale, a 13-year-old Black football star is idolized by his town’s mostly white inhabitants, until they turn on him.
item.dc:creator: David Barclay Moore
item.media:description: Cover illustration for “The Incredibly Human Henson Blayze.”
